attachments.title: Blendle
attachments.text:
Blendle is a Dutch online news platform that aggregates articles from a variety of newspapers and magazines and sells them on a pay-per-article basis. The key differences to similar websites are the participation by otherwise commercially unrelated news services in a single platform and the ability for registered users to easily pay a small price per article. It has been called an "iTunes for news" in various media.
The project was founded by Marten Blankesteijn and Alexander Klöpping. Blendle was backed by a Dutch government fund during its trial phase in April 2014. The service is currently directed at customers in the Netherlands and Germany, but can be accessed elsewhere. The service is planning to expand into the United States in 2016.

text: These guys are doin cool stuff to monetize a la carte journalism.

I think we're in a dead cat bounce in media economics; the rich (via endowments eg Guardian) and paywalled (WaPo, FT, NYT) are stabilized. But the thousands of reporters around the country who were laid off over the last decade-plus have all moved out of the profession. The ratio of flacks to reporters is now like 8-1 (was like 2-1) and the vast majority of stuff being created is noise rather than signal. I think Wu probably talks about this?

attachments.title: Employment picture darkens for journalists at digital outlets
attachments.text: It probably comes as no surprise that jobs for journalists at newspapers continue to disappear. But in a disturbing development, digital news jobs that had been replacing some of the legacy positions appear to have hit a plateau....
attachments.fallback: Columbia Journalism Review: Employment picture darkens for journalists at digital outlets

text: As reductive as it is the future of media needs to be "get people to consider it worth paying for" because the ones that keep our system healthy are the often-boring, the school board reporter and the city hall reporter and the state assembly reporter. They are the watchdogs.

Very much agreed. Which is why I think we need to subsidize quality reporting through some other revenue source than "# of clicks". As you mentioned, the quality news sources (WSJ, NYT, etc) have stabilized due to paywall revenue, but many of those subscribers are not the people who need to be "better informed" and the people who do need to be "better informed" aren't going to pay for it. But, as behavioral economics has shown over the last few decades, there are ways to trick people into getting their value worth. Ex. People _hate_ sunk costs. So there might be something in bundling a digital NYT with a Starbucks or McDonadls latte.
I.e. If they still want their coffee, but have to pay an amount that isn't disqualifying more (e.g. 20 cents), than maybe they'll try and get their $$$ worth

For those joining the call w/ CommonPlace today at 1pm, wanted to give a bit of a high-level overview. Our goal is to learn about their vision, the current state of their product, and assess if there’s a cultural match between our org and theirs and if their needs align with our capabilities. What I’m looking for is for each of us to ask questions that allow us to determine the amount of effort that it would take to achieve some of their and our goals with their platform.

attachments.title: For the ‘new yellow journalists,’ opportunity comes in clicks and bucks
attachments.text: Disillusioned college grads find a lucrative niche with a site that stokes the alt-right and plays fast and loose with facts.
